claim: If A was born before B, then A is older than B

supporting.text: By definition, being born earlier means a person has existed for a longer period of time, making them older.

attacks.text: By definition, being born earlier means a person has existed for a longer period of time, making them older.
This assumes no time travel or relativistic effects, which could theoretically make someone born earlier younger in some reference frames.
The argument ignores edge cases like cryogenic freezing, where someone born earlier might not have aged biologically.
Time travel and relativistic scenarios are purely hypothetical and don't apply to normal human aging.
Cryogenic freezing is extremely rare and doesn't change the fundamental definition of age based on birth order.

supporting.text: Age is calculated based on the time elapsed since birth, so a person born earlier will always have a higher age.

attacks.text: Age is calculated based on the time elapsed since birth, so a person born earlier will always have a higher age.
If time zones or calendar systems differ, the exact birth order may be ambiguous, making age comparison unreliable.
Standardized timekeeping (e.g., UTC) and calendar conversions resolve most ambiguities in birth order.
Relativistic time dilation means A could biologically age slower than B if they move at different velocities, despite birth order.
Cryogenic freezing or suspended animation could pause aging, making birth order irrelevant for biological age.

supporting.text: This is a fundamental principle of chronology and is universally accepted in all cultures and legal systems.

attacks.text: This is a fundamental principle of chronology and is universally accepted in all cultures and legal systems.
In some cultures, age is calculated differently, such as counting time in the womb or starting from conception, which could make someone born earlier technically younger in their system.
Even in cultures with alternative age-counting methods, the principle that being born earlier means being older still holds when using standard chronological age.
Legal systems sometimes recognize retroactive birth dates for administrative purposes, which can create exceptions where someone born earlier is legally younger.
Such legal exceptions are rare and don't change the biological fact that earlier birth means greater age, only the administrative record.

supporting.text: The concept of age is linear and directly tied to birth order; no exceptions exist in mainstream understanding.

attacks.text: The concept of age is linear and directly tied to birth order; no exceptions exist in mainstream understanding.
Time dilation in relativity means observers in different frames may disagree on birth order, breaking linearity.
Relativistic effects are negligible for human-scale events and don't affect legal/social age concepts.
Cryogenic freezing could pause biological aging while maintaining birth order, creating exceptions.
Cryopreservation is speculative technology without proven age-altering effects on revived humans.
Some cultures measure age from conception rather than birth, potentially reversing order comparisons.
International standards and scientific consensus define age from birth event, overriding cultural variations.
